claims_to_validate.claim_text: Current system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking of overtime and unpaid leaves.

The system shows a discrepancy in daily wage formula configuration between leave policy and payroll settings. The payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence and overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave deductions. The greyed-out display in leave policy indicates this override is intentional.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator is not correctly accounting for leap years in its calculation logic. When calculating gratuity for an employee with service spanning 2024 (a leap year), the system counts 365 days instead of 366 days for that year, resulting in an incorrect total service period (607 days instead of 608 days) and an incorrect gratuity amount (AED 10,476.98 instead of AED 10,494.24).

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses specific methodologies for counting days, accounting for leap years, and applying different daily rates based on service duration.

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), causing slight variations in total service days and resulting gratuity amount. The specific case showed a difference between 912 and 913 total days, impacting the final calculation.

Platform calculates days worked with a potential extra day (623 days instead of 622 days). Daily wage calculation uses a fixed divisor of 30 days, which differs from client's preferred method of (Basic × 12 / 365).

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system uses different divisors for leave salary (30 days) and salary proration (30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. This is a system design limitation where leave salary and salary proration use independent daily wage formulas.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing. When payroll is processed earlier than the departure date, the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes out of sync between Payroll and Time Off modules. This results in incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

The payroll system uses a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations, potentially causing confusion about calculation methods.
The system displays incorrect daily rate remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. Deductions are calculated using a global setting instead of policy-level basic salary / working days configuration.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is inconsistent with the leave period.
